Award.AwardTitle: Emergence, transmission and evolution of Tasmanian devil facial tumor disease
Award.AbstractNarration: Emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) are considered a grand challenge in the environmental sciences for the 21st century because of their effects on human, wildlife and agricultural health. Infectious diseases are now listed as the sixth leading cause of species extinctions, and an EID has caused the endangerment of the iconic Tasmanian devil. Across Tasmania, devil populations are being decimated by an infectious cancer called Tasmanian devil facial tumor disease. Although only a few infectious cancers are documented, this cancer shares properties with human cancers. This study will investigate how transmission is related to heterogeneity in contacts and genomic variation in host and/and or tumor within populations. Genetic studies may reveal underlying causes of devil facial tumor longevity, perhaps providing information on cancer recurrence in humans. Further, extensive background research on devils, including thousands of samples before and after die-offs, affords the rare opportunity to study genomic interactions of an infectious agent and its host across an entire species? range. These genomic studies will shed light on the genetic basis of relative susceptibility of devils to the tumor, thereby allowing managers to choose the best individuals for captive breeding programs. In addition, knowledge of rates and direction of past tumor spread enables the unique ability to predict the precise location of future infections. In turn, devil contact network modeling and genomic studies of populations expected to become infected will facilitate the testing of predictions regarding the course of epidemics in new populations. This knowledge may help in developing responses to future human epidemics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Our research focused on understanding the ecology and evolution of emergence and spread of a transmissible cancer in Tasmanian devils. Since 1996, this lethal pathogen has spread throughout the entire geographic range of the devil, causing localized population declines often exceeding 90%. The Tasmanian devil is now endangered, and early models suggested extinction of the species was imminent.

The primary result of the research supported herein suggests, however, that co-existence of devils and the cancer (devil facial tumor disease, or DFTD) is a more likely result. Our work provides multiple lines of evidence to show that devils are evolving resistance and/ or tolerance in response to DFTD. Firstly, genetic analyses suggest rapid evolution in particular regions of the genome associated with tumor recognition and presentation to the immune system, as well as presence of small numbers of genes associated with resistance to infection and survival in female devils. Secondly, long-term population studies show that despite initial model predictions, no populations have gone extinct, and some populations may even be recovering. Thirdly, new models suggest that these demographic patterns stem from the fact that DFTD is slow to cause mortality, and devils can successfully breed and produce uninfected offspring. Fourth, social contact network studies provide further support because disease transmission most likely occurs during the mating season, when animals bite one another most often. As a result, due to the long latency period of the disease, tumors are unlikely to reach a lethal size until young are weaned.  Fifth, although populations are predicted to decline as a result of DFTD infection, extinction of devils should occur only approximately 20% of the time, according to additional model predictions. Extinction of the tumor (predicted 50% of the time) or devil-tumor population cycles (predicted 30% of the time) are more likely. Sixth, recent evidence of spontaneous tumor regression has been found in an increasing number of individual Tasmanian devils. Tumor regression appears to result, at least in part, from successful immune responses, likely due variation in gene regulation. Evolution of DFTD may also contribute, as new mutations appear to be associated with gene expression linked to reduced tumor growth.

In summary, our work entailed an interdisciplinary approach that included genomics, field study and mathematical modeling for understanding the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of an emerging, transmissible cancer.  Working together, our team discovered multiple lines of evidence to suggest that devils and DFTD are evolving toward co-existence, as opposed to initial predictions of extinction.

Broader Impacts: The Tasmanian devil is a marquee example of a species threatened by an emerging infectious disease. Devils are an iconic Australian species and are a key component of the Tasmanian animal community. As a top predator, declines of Tasmanian devils has led, for example, to increases in feral cat populations and consequent declines in small, native Tasmanian mammals. Thus, conservation of Tasmanian devils is urgent. Our work now suggests that management should be geared toward coexistence of devils and DFTD, as opposed to preparation for extinction and reintroduction, because evolution of resistance appears to be occurring naturally.

Although devil facial tumor disease is a transmissible cancer, it is cancer, and shares properties with human cancer. Our studies of DFTD evolution may provide insights into human cancer evolution in two ways: 1) by understanding the ways in which cancer evades the immune system; and 2) elucidating the genetic mechanisms underlying documented spontaneous, natural tumor regression in animals in the field.
